awd_titl_txt: An Integrated Learning Theory of Descriptive and Experience-Based Decisions
awd_abstract_narration:
This research program will unify currently fragmented decision theories leading to a greater understanding of general decision making process beyond the traditional distinction of judgment and choice. Additionally, this research will provide insights into how decision options are evaluated over different attributes, and how they are ultimately selected under different amounts and types of information. Given that our decisions are often informed by some combination of explicitly described information and previous experience, this research is expected to have large impact in the multiple contexts in which we make decision every day, including financial, health, energy, and other contexts. The research may impact communication policies, the design of information and decision support systems, marketing strategies, and many other areas by clarifying what impact different amount, type, and format of information has on risk taking and decision making. This project will go beyond descriptions of phenomena by constructing behavior prediction algorithms. Because we will deliver computational implementations of the mental processes involved in making these decisions, this research has the potential to enhance and improve traditional technology of decision support and big data approaches used to predict decisions.

People make decisions by using information that varies in format, completeness, accuracy, certainty, and many other factors. Often, we rely on descriptive information (explicit definition of risks, outcomes, probabilities) and on experiential information (implicit collection of past outcomes and probabilities through feedback). Decisions that use both types of information are ubiquitous in both trivial, low-risk situations and highly consequential and risky situations, but most research deals with decisions made from descriptions or from experience exclusively; not a combination of both. This research undertakes a comprehensive integration of decision making theories and models, and proposes to generate a novel theory of descriptive and experience-based decisions. The research begins with performing a conceptual integration of the key psychological processes involved in judgment and choice in descriptive and experience-based decisions; second, establishes behavioral phenomena of the integration of these two types of information and their effects on choice; and third, proposes new computational formalizations to extend current models of learning to include the processes discovered through experimentation.

por.por_cntn:
DRMS: An Integrated Learning Theory of Descriptive and Experience-Based Decisions

Cleotilde Gonzalez

 

Our decisions rely on information that varies in format, completeness, accuracy, certainty, and many other factors.  Of particular relevance is a theoretical distinction made in the past decade regarding the effects of two types of information, description (explicit definition of risks, outcomes, probabilities) and experience (implicit collection of past outcomes and probabilities). Making decisions when either of these two types of information are available result in contrasting tendencies to take risks. When decisions are made from experience, people underweight the probability of rare (low probability) events, which may result in more risk taking; when decisions are made from description, people overweight the probability of rare events which may result in less risk taking. The choices made from description or experience are often different. This Description-Experience gap as encouraged development of decision theories that generally explain descriptive and others that explain experiential-based choices, but rarely both at the same time.

The current project addressed this issue by: (1) investigating experimentally how individuals make choices when both types of information are available, versus one or the other only; (2) creating cognitive models based on a theory of decisions from experience: Instance-Based Learning, that advances the computational representations of these types of information in memory; (3) setting models to test in international modeling competitions, against models that make different assumptions. The research resulted in 7 printed journal manuscripts and 3 currently in progress; 6 papers in juried conference proceedings; and 2 book chapters.  This research also advanced a number of tools for modeling and simulation that are made available to the public and used for teaching. Including: a Python architecture for building instance-Based Learning models (PyIBL), a set of libraries in R for IBL, and an implementation of a GUI for IBL to simulate IBL models of binary choice rapidly (ShinyIBL).

Intellectual merit of proposed activity. The research program resulted in novel behavioral insights into general decision making and cognitive processes by combining currently divergent lines of research in decision making. The research produced new theoretical models that build on past learning and feedback cognitive models to bring together decision making theories which were divided. The research revealed cognitive processes that underlie the accumulation of descriptive and experiential information; How do humans integrate and store such accumulated information; how a modeling framework can explain and predict decisions based on different sources of information (e.g., description or experience); what is the influence of information complexity on the decision making process, and other insights. This research program helped to unified fragmented theory leading to a greater understanding of general decision making process beyond the traditional distinction of judgment and choice, while providing practical insight into what influences preferences on the level of the individual.

Broader impacts of proposed activity. This research impacts decision making theories and understanding of real life decision situations, where multiple sources of information influence our decisions. Results from our basic research program have applications to various fields in engineering and computer science. These results provide insights into how decision options are evaluated over different attributes, and ultimately selected. This is clear by the various applications of the decision models proposed here to fields such as cybersecurity, dynamic resource allocation, and current research on spreading of information. The results were disseminated in through our high impact scientific publications, presentations at international conferences and workshops, and through outreach activities.
